questions.text: A 55-year-old man with SBP 170mmHg, with bounding-collapsing pulse and a hyperdynamic circulation. ECG shows features of LVH. He was diagnosed with hypertension several years back & is currently not on any medications. On further evaluation with Echocardiography, which of these statements is true regarding this condition? 1. Most common condition to develop in Congenital Bicuspid Aortic Valve (BAV) disease is coarctation of the aorta. 2. Syphilis and Ankylosing Spondylitis are conditions that involve Aortic Leaflets and can also cause Aortic Root Dilatation. 3. Secondary AR can be seen as a result of Membranous Sub-Aortic Stenosis. 4. In Rheumatic disease, aortic valve cusps are involved can cause the valve to not open properly during systole and not close completely during diastole. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, & 4 Patients with Congenital Bicuspid Aortic Valve (BAV) disease may develop predominant AR. Medial Degeneration with ascending aorta aneurysm/dissection is seen. Coarctation of the aorta is infrequent. Syphilis and ankylosing spondylitis, both of which affect the aortic leaflets , can also have cellular infiltration and scarring of the media of the thoracic aorta, leading to aortic dilation, aneurysm formation, and severe regurgitation. A high-velocity systolic jet that often leads to thickening and scarring of the aortic valve leaflets can be seen in Membranous Subaortic Stenosis , which can cause Secondary AR Rheumatic disease results in thickening, deformity, and shortening of the individual aortic valve cusps, changes that prevent their proper opening during systole and closure during diastole. Rheumatic disease increases the risk of development of Infective Endocarditis. Regurgitant lesions have a higher incidence of IE as compared to stenotic lesions

Highyeild:

ECHO :- Severe AR:- Regurgitant Volume :- _< 60ml Regurgitant Fraction:- >_50% If EF <50% If EF > 50% End diastolic Diameter > 65mm End systolic Diameter > 50mm

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, with complaints of rapidly developing dyspnea which progressed to the patient going into shock, was brought into the emergency. The patient is a known case of Infective Endocarditis and was started on treatment. A diagnosis of Acute Severe Aortic Regurgitation was made following an investigation. Which of the following statement is False regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute severe AORTIC REGURGITATION may respond to intravenous diuretics and vasodilators, but surgery is the Treatment of choice

options.label: B
options.text: IE, aortic dissection, or trauma are the common causes of the development of Acute Aortic Regurgitation

options.label: C
options.text: Intra-aortic Balloon Counterpulsation & Beta blockers are contraindicated

options.label: D
options.text: Traumatic rupture or avulsion of an aortic cusp is a common cause of acute AORTIC REGURGITATION

questions.correct_answer: D. Traumatic rupture or avulsion of an aortic cusp is a common cause of acute AORTIC REGURGITATION
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Traumatic rupture or avulsion of an aortic cusp is a common cause of acute AORTIC REGURGITATION In the case of Acute AORTIC REGURGITATION , the presentation is that of rapidly developing Pulmonary oedema and/or cardiogenic shock, so IV diuretics and Sodium Nitroprusside are helpful in symptomatic therapy, but the effect of these drugs is short-term. Surgical Intervention in the Treatment of choice in AR is usually necessary before 24Hrs of the onset of symptoms. Causes of development of acute AORTIC REGURGITATION are IE, aortic dissection, or Trauma.

Highyeild:

In Acute AORTIC REGURGITATION, Intra-aortic Balloon Counterpulsation is contraindicated as it increases regurgitation. IABP can be used in cardiogenic shock due to MI; however primary treatment remains PCI and thrombolysis for STEMI. Beta-blockers are also avoided as they can reduce the CO further or slow the heart rate, thus allowing more time for diastolic filling of the LV. Traumatic rupture or avulsion of an aortic cusp is an uncommon cause of acute AORTIC REGURGITATION, it represents the most frequent serious lesion in patients surviving nonpenetrating cardiac injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following findings & clinical signs are most consistent with Aortic Regurgitation? 1. Corrigan's Pulse 2. De Musset Sign 3. Duroziez's Sign 4. Quincke's Pulse 5. Austin Flint Murmur 6. Graham Steele Murmur 7. Slow Rising Pulse Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, 4, 5 Corrigan’s pulse: A rapidly rising “water-hammer” pulse, which collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole.

questions.text: A patient in his late 50s presents to the emergency department with complaints of having difficulty breathing which increases when he lies down and chest pains which are not relieved even after resting. He has had a long history of on/off "uncomfortable heartbeats" as told by the patient. An urgent ECG was ordered and the patient is found to show the following ECG changes, with normal sinus rhythm. Without further examination, which of the following is most likely to be a cause for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aortic Regurgitation The given ECG shows Left Ventricular Hypertrophy which is most probably due to long-standing volume overload as seen in Aortic Regurgitation.

Highyeild:

Tall R waves: V5/6 R >=25 mm or V1S+V5/6 R>-35 mm (sokolow lyon criteria for diagnosis of LVH on ecg) Deeply inverted T waves in the left-sided chest leads, and deep S waves in the right-sided leads. ECHO :- Severe AR :- Regurgitant Volume :- ≥ 60ml Regurgitant fraction:-> 50% If EF <50% If EF > 50% End diastolic diameter > 65mm End systolic diameter > 50mm

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. In the case of Mitral regurgitation, the ECG shows the features of left atrial delay (bifid P waves) along with 'eccentric' left ventricular hypertrophy. The history in MR is that of Fatigue and Lethargy which develop because of the reduced cardiac output, and which also leads to Cardiac Cachexia further in the disease course. Option: C. Myocardial Infarction will have sudden onset severe pain which would also have a history of CAD. ECG would show ST-segment elevation. Option: D. Myocarditis will show ECG changes suggestive of pericarditis or acute myocardial infarction, and occasionally with atrial or ventricular tachyarrhythmias

ECG:- LVH :- Left axis deviation Left atrial enlargement + ECHO :- Severe AR:- Regurgitant Volume :- _< 60ml Regurgitant Fraction:- >_50% If EF <50% If EF > 50% End diastolic Diameter > 65mm End systolic Diameter > 50mm

Solution:

1-Chronic AR, 2-Acute AR, 3-AS, 4-MR This is most consistent with the findings of Acute AR, which is usually due to IE, Aortic Dissection, or Trauma, there is no long-term compensation noted as in chronic, so there is no LVH. Also, sudden Pulmonary oedema and cardiogenic shock are the common sequelae.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. This is most consistent with the findings of Chronic Aortic Regurgitation will show a Wide Pulse pressure along with LVH and Aortic Root Dilatation in case of Root involvement. Option: C. This is most consistent with the findings of Aortic Stenosis, elderly patients might have HTN, AND in severe cases, the pulse pressure becomes very Narrow . LVH is also a common finding. Option: D. This is most consistent with the findings of MR, where there is LA Dilatation and features of LVH seen in ECG in around 50% of patients. Whereas, Echocardiography reveals Dilated LA & LV.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man came with complaints of intense chest and back pain and was evaluated further. His Chest x-ray reveals a widened superior mediastinum. An urgent CT scan shows Stanford Type-A Aortic Dissection and Echocardiography reveals Severe AR. Which of these statements is true regarding this condition? 1. Acute aortic regurgitation is an important and common complication of proximal aortic dissection. 2. Hypertension, Atherosclerosis, Aortitis, Marfan Syndrome, Bicuspid aortic valve and Infective Endocarditis are some of the causes leading to this condition. 3. Neurologic conditions like hemiplegia, hemianesthesia, or spinal cord ischemia (paraplegia). Bowel ischemia, hematuria, and myocardial ischemia may occur. 4. An electrocardiogram that almost always shows evidence of myocardial ischemia. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2, & 3 are correct Aortic Dissection Stanford Type A involves the ascending aorta independent of the site of tear and distal extension . TOC is a surgical intervention. Presenting complaints are usually pain, localized to the front or back of the chest, often the interscapular region, and typically migrates with the propagation of the dissection.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Explanation-1. In the case of Aortic Dissection involving Ascending Aorta, Acute severe AR is seen in patients. AR in these patients is the outcome of either a circumferential tear that widens the aortic root or a disruption of the annulus by a dissecting hematoma that tears a leaflet(s) or displaces it, inferior to the line of closure Explanation 2. Degenerative disorders ( Hypercholesterolemia Hypertension Atherosclerosis) , Genetic/developmental disorders ( Marfan’s syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV, Aneurysm-osteoarthritis syndrome, Bicuspid aortic valve, Turner’s syndrome), Aortitis, Pregnancy, Traum All these conditions predispose one to develop Aortic Dissection. Explanation 3. Carotid artery obstruction due to dissection can lead to N eurological Deficits . Explanation 4 . Electrocardiogram shows no evidence of myocardial ischemia that can be helpful in distinguishing between myocardial ischemia and aortic dissection. Myocardial Ischemia is a rarity seen only in Aortic Dissection which involves coronary ostium.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male who presented with chest discomfort was brought in cardiology OPD and was found to have BP160/60mmHg, evaluated and was found to have Aortic Regurgitation. Which of the following condition is NOT responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atrial Fibrillation Aortic Regurgitation leads to LV hypertrophy. Whereas, LA enlargement is a finding in MR , which is seen along with atrial fibrillation in some cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. IE can be a cause for both MR and AR and is also known to involve both the Mitral valve and Aortic Valve at the same time. Option: C. Marfan’s syndrome (MFS) is a connective tissue disorder with autosomal dominant inheritance. This syndrome can affect the eyes, lungs, skeletal system and cardiovascular system. Both MR and AR can be seen in MFS. Option: D. Rheumatic Fever can lead to the involvement of both Mitral as well as Aortic Valves.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient referred from Ophthalmology OPD was found to have a high arch palate, ectopia lentis, sunken sternum, & long limbs in the examination. He was also complaining of palpitations for a few years & the jarring of the entire body. The physician also noted the bobbing motion of the head with each systole. Which of the following statement about his condition is false?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Mainstay pharmacological treatment for the cardiological manifestations in this condition will comprise beta blockers and ARBs

options.label: C
options.text: Aortic Regurgitation, Aortic Dissection, or Aortic Dilatation any of these conditions can be seen in this patient

options.label: D
options.text: Valvular pathologies are not seen in this condition and patient rarely succumbs to cardiovascular causes

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Valvular pathologies are not seen in this condition and patient rarely succumbs to cardiovascular causes Given the History and findings, this is a case of Marfan Syndrome. Valvular Function may be impaired in Marfan Syndrome patients along with aortic root dilatation. Whereas, the primary cause of death in Marfan Syndrome is cardiovascular.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of Dyspnea, Excessive Diaphoresis, and Anginal pain at rest as well as during exertion. He was evaluated in the emergency and was found to have Raised SBP with wide pulse pressure. ECG findings were only showing LVH changes. An echocardiography was done and the patient was found to have Aortic Regurgitation. All of the following are Indications for Surgery in this patient, EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: The patient is symptomatic, which goes to prove that LV systolic Dysfunction has set in the pathology of the heart

options.label: B
options.text: The Echo Findings Show LVEF<50% in this patient

options.label: C
options.text: The Dyspnea and chest pain points towards Acute Aortic Regurgitation, and the patient should be operated on after stabilization with diuretics and Vasodilators

options.label: D
options.text: The End-Systolic LV Diameter is >50mm in this patient

questions.correct_answer: C. The Dyspnea and chest pain points towards Acute Aortic Regurgitation, and the patient should be operated on after stabilization with diuretics and Vasodilators
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The Dyspnea and chest pain points towards Acute Aortic Regurgitation, and the patient should be operated on after stabilization with diuretics and Vasodilators Dyspnea In a patient of Acute AR sets in Rapidly due to Rapidly developing Pulmonary Edema. Also, Acute AR is usually not associated with LV changes like LVH.

Highyeild:

This is a case of AR, which is most likely a long-standing Chronic AR. Aortic surgery INDICATIONS: Acute severe AR Symptomatic Chronic AR patients (dyspnea, NYHA class II-IV, angina) Asymptomatic patients with an LVEF of -50% Asymptomatic patients with an LVEF of >50% but with a dilated LV (end-diastolic systolic dimension >50mm) Patients undergoing CABG or surgery of the ascending aorta or another cardiac valve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The protocol for surgery in a patient of Chronic AR is that any patient who is symptomatic should be Operated on. Surgery is indicated for patients with severe AR and symptoms, LV dysfunction, or other indications for operation (e.g., aneurysm disease). Options: B & D. The ECHO findings of LVEF< 50% and End-Systolic LV Diameter>50mm are also indications for surgery even in an ASYMPTOMATIC patient.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion along with chest pain and excessive sweating. He was found to have wide pulse pressure, a bounding-collapsing type of pulse. His other medical history is that of Ankylosing Spondylitis. On auscultation, murmur was heard. If the auscultation is done properly, all the following features will be noted EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: High-Pitched Crescendo Decrescendo Type Mid-Systolic Murmur (Diamond Shaped murmur)

options.label: B
options.text: Soft, Low Pitched, Rumbling Mid-Late Diastolic Murmur

options.label: D
options.text: High Pitched Decrescendo Early Diastolic Murmur

questions.correct_answer: A. High-Pitched Crescendo Decrescendo Type Mid-Systolic Murmur (Diamond Shaped murmur)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High-Pitched Crescendo Decrescendo Type Mid-Systolic Murmur (Diamond Shaped murmur) The given picture of the clinical scenario is that of Chronic Aortic Regurgitation. Typically, the patient starts with High Pitched Decrescendo Early Diastolic Murmur heard best in the third intercostal space along the left sternal border, which INCREASES in duration as the disease progresses and becomes HOLO-DIASTOLIC murmur. Crescendo Decrescendo Type Mid-Systolic Murmur is characteristic of Aortic Stenosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Soft, Low Pitched, Rumbling Mid-Late Diastolic Murmur which is called Austin Flint Murmur Option: C. Mid Systolic Ejection Murmur is also found in AR and is best heard at the apex. Option: D. High-Pitched Decrescendo Early Diastolic Murmur is found in AR and is best heard at 3rd intercoastal space.

Extraedge:

Other Auscultatory Finding in AR A2 is usually absent Murmur is Heard best with the diaphragm of the stethoscope and with the patient sitting up, leaning forward, and with the breath held in forced expiration. A mid-systolic ejection murmur is frequently audible. It is due to increased LV Pressure. In Patients with severe AR, the Austin Flint murmur, which is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur, is noted. It is produced by the diastolic displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream The auscultatory features of AR are intensified by strenuous and sustained handgrip, which augments systemic vascular resistance and increases LV afterload

questions.text: A patient is in follow-up to check for the progression of his Chronic Severe AR. He was diagnosed with Severe AR 6 months back and is still relatively asymptomatic. What about the management of this patient is true? 1. All cases of severe chronic AR should be operated within 1 year of diagnosis of the AR. 2. Patient should be operated within 1 year of diagnosis of LV dysfunction. 3. Patient should be followed up on a 6- to 12-month basis so as to monitor the progress of AR & LV function. 4. Patients on Medications can defer surgical intervention as long as necessary even after being symptomatic. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3 are correct Statement 2 . The timing of surgical treatment is after the onset of LV dysfunction but prior to the development of severe symptoms, which is 1 year from the start of symptom or LV dysfunction . Statement 3 . In patients with chronic severe AR, careful clinical follow-up and noninvasive testing with echocardiography at 6- to 12-month intervals are necessary. Monitoring is CRUCIAL as, whenever unchecked for too long i.e., >1 year from onset of symptoms or LV dysfunction, surgical treatment often does not restore normal LV size and function.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Statement 1 - All cases of severe chronic AR, who are symptomatic, should be operated on, irrespective of the LV Functionality. In the case of Asymptomatic patients, the progression of disease, and LV dysfunction is evaluated. Statement 4. The operation can be deferred only on the grounds that, the patient both remains asymptomatic and retains normal LV function without severe or progressive chamber dilation.

questions.explanation:

Rheumatic Heart Disease The coexistence of hemodynamically significant aortic stenosis (AS) with AR usually excludes all the rarer forms of AR because it occurs almost exclusively in patients with Rheumatic or congenital AR.
